<span style=""color: rgb(106, 106, 106)
column8: >A few years ago I started making loud, fun rock music for my girls to give them something to sing along to. The music was written in the spirit of the fun older tunes of the likes of Weezer and so forth with an electronic leaning.

column1: Now, it's morphed into a very encouraging, ongoing family project that is Chibi Kodama. We sing about our fights, triumphs, laughter and sadness.

Our newest project, ""Stardust"" is our most passionate yet. We've never been more satisfied or excited to share our creation with the world, and we'd like your help to make it happen in the biggest way that we can. 

What We Need &
column2:
What You Get

We would love your financial help to get as wide of a release as we possibly can: 

  • Our basic goal is $1000, this would get us a huge batch of CDs printed by the pros (none of this home-made stuff we've done for years

column1:
• Aid us in what will be needed in presenting our newest project to the Children's/Kindie music industry at large, as well as enable us to have the gear we need for traveling and spreading the love!
  • Our perks include everything from early downloads of the newest album, our entire back catalog of tunes, t-shirts, custom made art, stickers and more!
  • If... if we do not reach our goal, the first of the funds will go directly to CD production. This is our first priority. The reason for this is pretty singular - we're not trying to make a living doing this, we're trying to share the love that we've been given. It's a blessing, and there are few things that bring me as much joy as handing out a free CD as we travel to a family that will sing along and join in.
<h3><span style=""color: rgb(106, 106, 106)
column8: >Well, help us if you believe in this. We're a bizarre, wacky family. We know very well that our music isn't for everyone. But those that it is for, we've seen it greatly encourage them. And we want to do it more.

column1: <h3><span style=""color: rgb(106, 106, 106)
column8: >You can help to make that happen.

column1: <div><span style=""color: rgb(106, 106, 106)
column9:
Challenges

There are always risks, but we see very few at this stage. Maybe we're just naive. But, being that we're not trying to get rich here, we've got little to lose. The album is in the final stages of recording and mixing. We do that in house. (quite literally)

column1: The more support we get, the further that we'll be able to take our passion project here.

Other Ways You Can Help

Don't have the cash, but still believe in what we're doing? Great!
Please tell your friends. Spread the word and help us make it happen.
","In short...

A few years ago I started making loud, fun rock music for my girls to give them something to sing along to. The music was written in the spirit of the fun older tunes of the likes of Weezer and so forth with an electronic leaning.
Now, it's morphed into a very encouraging, ongoing family project that is Chibi Kodama. We sing about our fights, triumphs, laughter and sadness.

Our newest project, ""Stardust"" is our most passionate yet. We've never been more satisfied or excited to share our creation with the world, and we'd like your help to make it happen in the biggest way that we can.    What We Need & What You Get We would love your financial help to get as wide of a release as we possibly can:   Our basic goal is $1000, this would get us a huge batch of CDs printed by the pros (none of this home-made stuff we've done for years

Aid us in what will be needed in presenting our newest project to the Children's/Kindie music industry at large, as well as enable us to have the gear we need for traveling and spreading the love! Our perks include everything from early downloads of the newest album, our entire back catalog of tunes, t-shirts, custom made art, stickers and more! If... if we do not reach our goal, the first of the funds will go directly to CD production. This is our first priority. The reason for this is pretty singular - we're not trying to make a living doing this, we're trying to share the love that we've been given. It's a blessing, and there are few things that bring me as much joy as handing out a free CD as we travel to a family that will sing along and join in.
Why should you help?

Well, help us if you believe in this. We're a bizarre, wacky family. We know very well that our music isn't for everyone. But those that it is for, we've seen it greatly encourage them. And we want to do it more.
You can help to make that happen.

Risks & Challenges There are always risks, but we see very few at this stage. Maybe we're just naive. But, being that we're not trying to get rich here, we've got little to lose. The album is in the final stages of recording and mixing. We do that in house. (quite literally)
The more support we get, the further that we'll be able to take our passion project here.
Other Ways You Can Help Don't have the cash, but still believe in what we're doing? Great!
Please tell your friends. Spread the word and help us make it happen.",0.0,0,"2 Campaigns
|","Selmer, United States",https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/chibi-kodama-stardust-cd-release/pica
0,"<div class=""routerContentStory-storyBody"" data-v-1df7bf5a=""""><div> <h3>
<h3>The Before &amp
For my third EP, I’m doing something quite different and I’m really excited about it.
<ol>
<li><span style=""font-weight: normal
column2: >It’s going to be an acoustic EP: Always wanted to try it, now’s the chance.

column1: <li><span style=""font-weight: normal
column2: >It will be recorded and produced entirely for free with the help of friends and a little extra time, so I don’t have to raise any money for that!

column1: <li><span style=""font-weight: normal
column2: >It will be entirely inspired by a two week trip to Asia where I will be spending time with friends who are serving the disadvantaged, specifically those vulnerable to various forms of oppression, including human trafficking.

column1: What to expect from this EP? The length will be six songs
column2: three that I will write leading up to the departure of my trip and three that I will write upon returning. What I hope to experience and to share is the transformation that takes place in my heart. I have fears, anticipations, motives, preconceptions and so many other things going on in my head that I believe will be deeply impacted by this trip. I hope to come out the other end as someone who will write better songs and tell a clearer version of the stories we’re formed by. There’s so much beauty in life, and yet so much suffering. I want to be better at dealing with this tension and making a positive difference amidst it.

column1: <h3><b>How you can help &amp
Here’s where I need your help
column2: I don’t have the means to cover the additional costs that this trip presents, so all funds raised will go towards covering the following:

column1: Approximate Total Cost: $3,500
Estimated breakdown:
<ul>
• Flight: $1600
• Hotel: $500
• Food: $600
• Visa: $90
• Vaccines: $300
• Other travel: $80
• Spending: $80
• Indiegogo Processing Fees (5%, 3rd Party 3%): $250
The Impact

With your help, I can participate in this life-changing trip, encourage friends in their life-giving work and complete an EP that shares the journey my heart and mind are led on. To say thank you for giving to this project, I’ve set up different thank you packages that are yours to claim including pictures, journal excerpts and the songs from the EP. Check them out in the perks! I’m excited to have you along for this story.
Beyond the EP...

If you were wondering, I won’t be travelling alone! I’m glad to be going with friends of mine, who are family to me, to encourage our friends in Asia. All money raised beyond my goal will go towards helping cover the travel costs of others in our team and to support the on-the-ground work in Asia. To help keep production costs as low as possible, this EP will be distributed digitally only.
Other ways to help

Maybe this is something that your network, friends, family or followers would be interested in following or investing in. If this is something you’d like to see happen, please share this campaign with your community to help make this trip and this EP possible!
Also keep in touch with me over Facebook, Twitter or Instagram to see the ongoing adventures of my music.
Thanks so much for your time and consideration towards this project.
Sincerely yours,
Joey
","The Before & After Concept
For my third EP, I’m doing something quite different and I’m really excited about it.
It’s going to be an acoustic EP: Always wanted to try it, now’s the chance.
It will be recorded and produced entirely for free with the help of friends and a little extra time, so I don’t have to raise any money for that!

It will be entirely inspired by a two week trip to Asia where I will be spending time with friends who are serving the disadvantaged, specifically those vulnerable to various forms of oppression, including human trafficking.
What to expect from this EP? The length will be six songs
column2: three that I will write leading up to the departure of my trip and three that I will write upon returning. What I hope to experience and to share is the transformation that takes place in my heart. I have fears, anticipations, motives, preconceptions and so many other things going on in my head that I believe will be deeply impacted by this trip. I hope to come out the other end as someone who will write better songs and tell a clearer version of the stories we’re formed by. There’s so much beauty in life, and yet so much suffering. I want to be better at dealing with this tension and making a positive difference amidst it.

column1: How you can help & how I thank you!
Here’s where I need your help
column2: I don’t have the means to cover the additional costs that this trip presents, so all funds raised will go towards covering the following:

column1: Approximate Total Cost: $3,500
Estimated breakdown:
Flight: $1600
Hotel: $500
Food: $600
Visa: $90
Vaccines: $300
Other travel: $80
Spending: $80
Indiegogo Processing Fees (5%, 3rd Party 3%): $250
The Impact

With your help, I can participate in this life-changing trip, encourage friends in their life-giving work and complete an EP that shares the journey my heart and mind are led on. To say thank you for giving to this project, I’ve set up different thank you packages that are yours to claim including pictures, journal excerpts and the songs from the EP. Check them out in the perks! I’m excited to have you along for this story.
Beyond the EP...

If you were wondering, I won’t be travelling alone! I’m glad to be going with friends of mine, who are family to me, to encourage our friends in Asia. All money raised beyond my goal will go towards helping cover the travel costs of others in our team and to support the on-the-ground work in Asia. To help keep production costs as low as possible, this EP will be distributed digitally only.
Other ways to help

Maybe this is something that your network, friends, family or followers would be interested in following or investing in. If this is something you’d like to see happen, please share this campaign with your community to help make this trip and this EP possible!
Also keep in touch with me over Facebook, Twitter or Instagram to see the ongoing adventures of my music.
Thanks so much for your time and consideration towards this project.
Sincerely yours,
Joey",0.0,0,"4 Campaigns

The Story in Brief

Help the New York Jazzharmonic premiere a composition penned in 1987 by music legend Fred Hellerman, and never before performed in public.  Fred was an original member of The Weavers, founded in the 1950's by him and the legendary Pete Seeger.

  • For the last 29+ years, Fred has been waiting to hear an orchestra perform his 10 minute masterpiece, ""Fourths of July.""
<li>
The New York Jazzharmonic is a big band that plays primarily swinging jazz, but with strong crossover elements of classical and world music.
• The free concert is set for Tuesday, June, 28, 2016 as part of the Washington Square Music Festival.  We expect an audience of close to 2,000 people.
• While on in years and unable to travel comfortably these days, Fred is as excited as can be to hear the composition played by live musicians.

Please help us with the considerable costs of presenting this wonderful patriotic extravaganza in the Fourth of July season, which is a theme and variations on Yankee Doodle Dandy, and other American traditional and original themes.

The New  York Jazzharmonic at the 2015 Washington Square Music Festival

Our costs for this historic performance.

The Washington Square Music Festival is presenting our band, and helping us pay our musicians, however there are considerable extra costs in presenting this world premiere performance.

  • Honorarium for Fred. $1,000. Of course Fred is entitled to a fee for the performance of his composition.
• Re-orchestration. $1,000.  Fred's original score is for full symphonic ensemble with string section.  We need to re-orchestrate the piece for our 17 member big band.
• Score and parts typesetting and printing. $1,000.  A new score for the conductor and parts for the players must be produced.
• Extra rehearsal for the piece.  $855.  Our musicians get paid under a union contract per rehearsal.
• Possible extra musicians, app. $300 each.  It may be that we need to hire an extra percussionist or piccolo player to add on to our band to fully realize the work.
• Video filming and post production.  $500-$1,000.  We would like to have a high quality video of this one-time-only performance so that as many of Fred's fans as possible can see this.
• Fred's Transportation: $200-$300.  We'd like to arrange for a driver and limousine to bring Fred down in style and comfort to Greenwich Village from his home in Connecticut.
• Any money raised above our goal will go into a fund to premiere other neglected works by composers from various fields of music.
Ron Wasserman and Fred Hellerman
New York Jazzharmonic
• By the end of our first year of existence we will have played world premieres by 9 composers, culminating in this performace, which is a long overdue honor for our dear friend Fred.
• We have an annual season at the Leonard Nimoy Thalia Symphony Space.
• This is one of the most exciting things that artistic director Ron
Wasserman has done in his 35 year professional career, and the most
important premiere the new York Jazzharmonic has done in our existence.
Visit our web site for information: www.nyjazzharmonic.org
Like us on Facebook. www.facebook.com/newyorkjazzharmonic
Fred Hellerman quote:
“If you can exist, and stay the course — not a course of blind obstinacy and faulty conception, but one of decency and good sense — you can outlast your enemies with your honor and integrity intact.”

Get to know us

Late Night Special are a four-man band based out of Mount Pleasant, North Carolina that combine a sounds of folk, indie rock, and pop mixed with a relaxed vibe.

  • We've been pumping out songs and beats on our own for the past 2 years, squeezed in between shifts, sales, sets, and The Shakedown.
  • Our first album, Light of the Moon,  was a smashing success and has given us great momentum since it was released -- shows, festivals, private shows, and more.
  • We're Fred Heintz on Vocals and Guitar, Bradley Cannon on Drums, Derek Furr on Guitar, and Rob Shoemaker on Bass. Just some local boys with a passion for music and letting others in on that.
• LISTEN TO OUR SOUND ON OUR SOUNDCLOUD

Be Part of the Awesomeness

Here's the deal:
<span style=""background-color: initial
column2: >We need cash to be able to pay our production costs, travel to the recording studio, printing of the album, advertising, distribution costs, and hopefully lay down some funds to bring our sounds from the Piedmont to the Foothills, Mountains, and Beach of North Carolina -- and beyond!

column1: <li><span style=""background-color: initial
column2:
>With the $2,000, we'll have all the costs covered from recording costs -- that's studio time, the producers, tuning up of the instruments, and food to keep us sane during the whole process. It's an investment.
  • If we can build up capital, then hopefully we can put together a Tour of the South once the album launches!

    • The Impact

    You've seen our work with The Shakedown, the yearly music festival hosted in Concord, NC -- dozens of musical acts, plenty of cornhole, beer, great sounds, art, and camping abound. So you know we're good for every penny.

    • By investing in Late Night Special, you're helping to launch a local band to the level where its music belongs.

column1: The Shakedown began as a small group of friends camping out and playing music. Within a few years, it has turned into a full-blown festival with sponsors, vendors, big sound and big bands. It's become an institution. Learn more here.

• We want to take our music to the next level by really producing a professional album we can hopefully take to promoters and labels.

    • It Won't Be Easy

    Independent music is a tough business. We're competing with people who have more experience, more money, and more time to invest. That's why we need your help.

    • If we can get our fans to support us, we'll be able to bring our music to thousands more people.
    • We've equipped ourselves with a legal structure as an LLC, hired a band manager, and really tried to professionalize our operations.

    How You Can Help

    If times are tough and you can't spare the extra change, you can still help:

    • Use Facebook, Twitter, Reddit, and everything else in your online toolbox to get the word about our campaign!

column1: ","Get to know us

Late Night Special are a four-man band based out of Mount Pleasant, North Carolina that combine a sounds of folk, indie rock, and pop mixed with a relaxed vibe.  We've been pumping out songs and beats on our own for the past 2 years, squeezed in between shifts, sales, sets, and The Shakedown. Our first album, Light of the Moon,  was a smashing success and has given us great momentum since it was released -- shows, festivals, private shows, and more. We're Fred Heintz on Vocals and Guitar, Bradley Cannon on Drums, Derek Furr on Guitar, and Rob Shoemaker on Bass. Just some local boys with a passion for music and letting others in on that.
LISTEN TO OUR SOUND ON OUR SOUNDCLOUD
Be Part of the Awesomeness Here's the deal:

We need cash to be able to pay our production costs, travel to the recording studio, printing of the album, advertising, distribution costs, and hopefully lay down some funds to bring our sounds from the Piedmont to the Foothills, Mountains, and Beach of North Carolina -- and beyond!

With the $2,000, we'll have all the costs covered from recording costs -- that's studio time, the producers, tuning up of the instruments, and food to keep us sane during the whole process. It's an investment. If we can build up capital, then hopefully we can put together a Tour of the South once the album launches!    The Impact You've seen our work with The Shakedown, the yearly music festival hosted in Concord, NC -- dozens of musical acts, plenty of cornhole, beer, great sounds, art, and camping abound. So you know we're good for every penny.  By investing in Late Night Special, you're helping to launch a local band to the level where its music belongs.

The Shakedown began as a small group of friends camping out and playing music. Within a few years, it has turned into a full-blown festival with sponsors, vendors, big sound and big bands. It's become an institution. Learn more here.

We want to take our music to the next level by really producing a professional album we can hopefully take to promoters and labels.    It Won't Be Easy  Independent music is a tough business. We're competing with people who have more experience, more money, and more time to invest. That's why we need your help.  If we can get our fans to support us, we'll be able to bring our music to thousands more people. We've equipped ourselves with a legal structure as an LLC, hired a band manager, and really tried to professionalize our operations.    How You Can Help If times are tough and you can't spare the extra change, you can still help:  Use Facebook, Twitter, Reddit, and everything else in your online toolbox to get the word about our campaign! Sign-up for our mailing list to get all the latest updates on this campaign!",0.0,1,"1 Campaign

Welcome! 

We are the Hartka-Lezcano cello &
column2:
guitar duo

As you watch the video, enjoy musical clips of our live performance of Sonatas by Lezcano and Gnattali. 

We are thrilled to have received an invitation to perform a concert tour of Cuba in March 2017 from UNEAC (the Cuban National Union of Writers, Artists, &
column3:
Composers). 

The trip will be an opportunity to soak up the rich music of the region, exchange ideas and make new friends. With your support we can offer masterclasses to Cuban music students, perform and research the beautiful music of the area to prepare for a CD recording of music by Cuban and Brazilian composers! In addition, you can send me to Cuba with a cello to be donated. It is only possible for a US citizen to legally donate towards cultural enrichment in Cuba since the Obama administration lightened the restrictions in January 2015.

column1: Johnson string Instrument and the Boston Cello Society are collaborating in the project to bring an instrument and strings to the under resourced  musicians of Cuba.
About us:

Described by Fanfare Magazine as “an excellent guitarist as well as an imaginative composer,” Jose Lezcano is a twice Grammy-nominated composer and performer who has concertized on four continents. His programs featuring traditional and Latin American repertory, and his own original Latin-inspired compositions have taken him as recitalist, collaborative musician, and concerto soloist from Carnegie Recital Hall and the North-South Consonance Series in New York City to major venues and festivals in Spain, Ecuador, Colombia, Peru, Crete, Brazil, China, the Czech Republic and Germany.
http://www.joselezcano.com/

Cellist Rebecca Hartka has concertized for over a decade in venues throughout the United States as well as making international appearances in Italy, Vietnam, and Thailand. Hartka's playing was described by the Hanoi Times as ""... magical and eloquent."" Committed to building bridges through performance Hartka has performed in nontraditional venues such as Club Passim in Cambridge, Massachusetts, the Hampshire County Jail, numerous coffee houses and private homes, and such prestigious venues as the American Embassy in Hanoi. According to the Boston Musical Intelligencer her 2014 release Light &
column2: Shadow: Sonatas of Rachmaninov and Poulenc with pianist Alys Terrien-Queen ""take this rich Russian music to new heights"", stating that their performance ""ranks comfortably alongside several impressive readings by other major cellists."" Hartka earned her Doctorate of Musical Arts and Masters in Music from Boston University College of Fine Arts, and her Bachelor of Arts in Music from Oberlin College and Conservatory. She has studied with Andor Toth, Michael Reynolds, Rhonda Rider, and Leslie Parnas.

column1: http://rebeccahartka.com/
More about the Cuba Project

As a duo travelling to Cuba we have the opportunity to be cultural ambassadors, to build bridges through music across language and country, to nurture understanding, compassion and respect for our shared human experience. Our goal is to give voice to an underrepresented community in the Classical music field, and bring something back to share with our community. Our intention is to record a CD of music for cello and guitar by Cuban, Brazilian, Argentinian and American composers. Included on the CD would be Lezcano’s own duo.
Costs

One of the largest expenses associated with this project is the cost of purchasing the cello to be donated. IN addition, traveling with a cello and bow requires an extra airplane seat, as cellos cannot be checked as baggage. The other large expense is the cost of studio time. We have chosen to work with the Fraser studio at WGBH in Boston, and though they have a reasonable rate, it takes about 15 hours of recording time to create a one hour CD. Other costs include editing, printing and production of the CD.
A basic break down of costs:
$3, 000 Cello and Bow
$1,000 plane tickets
$1,300 tour costs
$3,500 CD recording
Risks

We run the risk of falling short of the fundraising goal. This is an ambitious endeavor, and we have little of our own money to devote to this project. If we are unable to reach our goal, we will simply take our time with CD project, recording as we have the money to fund it. Since we have already committed to our trip to Cuba, the tour and travel expenses will take first priority.
Please note, as of January 2015, it IS legal to donate goods beyond food and medicine to Cuba from the USA. I quote a document from the Covington Law Firm:
The BIS rule also enacts changes that
seek to facilitate donations to Cuba and promote civil society and human
rights. License <b>Exception SCP permits
the donation of items to Cuba for use in scientific, archaeological, cultural,
ecological, educational, historic preservation, or sporting activities, as
well as the temporary export of such items for up to two years by persons departing
the United States. The license exception also authorizes the export of certain
items to human rights organizations, individuals, or non-governmental
organizations that promote independent activity intended to strengthen civil
society, and the export of certain items to media personnel in Cuba engaged in
the dissemination of news to the general public. In addition, BIS expanded
License Exception Gift Parcels and Humanitarian Donations (“GFT”) to allow
consolidated shipments to Cuba of multiple parcels of qualified gifts or
donations without a license.
Heres a link to the full PDF document:
https://www.cov.com/~/media/files/corporate/publications/2015/01/us_treasury_and_commerce_departments_issue_amended_regulations_to_ease_us_sanctions_against_cuba.pdf
And a link to the US treasury department website outlining these changes
<div><ul style=""font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif
column4:
type=""disc"">
  • To strengthen civil society, SCP will authorize export and reexport of donated items and temporary export and reexport by travelers to Cuba of items for use in scientific, archaeological, cultural, ecological, educational, historic preservation, or sporting activities.  SCP will also authorize exports and reexports to human rights organizations, individuals, or non-governmental organizations that promote independent activity intended to strengthen civil society.

column1: <div>
https://www.treasury.gov/press-center/press-rel...
In conclusion

Cultural exchange is possible through the language of music. When musicians from different cultures connect across barriers, it creates a more peaceful and humane world. Education for fellow musicians in Cuba means that opportunity for talented music students can be more fully developed and share with their community. Bringing different voices into the Classical field brings richness and vibrance. Donating a cello is a pioneering effort only legally available to US citizens as of 18 months ago.
If you are unable to donate
You can support our project by letting other people know about our fundraising efforts by sharing on social media.

","Welcome! We are the Hartka-Lezcano cello & guitar duoAs you watch the video, enjoy musical clips of our live performance of Sonatas by Lezcano and Gnattali. We are thrilled to have received an invitation to perform a concert tour of Cuba in March 2017 from UNEAC (the Cuban National Union of Writers, Artists, & Composers). The trip will be an opportunity to soak up the rich music of the region, exchange ideas and make new friends. With your support we can offer masterclasses to Cuban music students, perform and research the beautiful music of the area to prepare for a CD recording of music by Cuban and Brazilian composers! In addition, you can send me to Cuba with a cello to be donated. It is only possible for a US citizen to legally donate towards cultural enrichment in Cuba since the Obama administration lightened the restrictions in January 2015.
Johnson string Instrument and the Boston Cello Society are collaborating in the project to bring an instrument and strings to the under resourced  musicians of Cuba.
About us:

Described by Fanfare Magazine as “an excellent guitarist as well as an imaginative composer,” Jose Lezcano is a twice Grammy-nominated composer and performer who has concertized on four continents. His programs featuring traditional and Latin American repertory, and his own original Latin-inspired compositions have taken him as recitalist, collaborative musician, and concerto soloist from Carnegie Recital Hall and the North-South Consonance Series in New York City to major venues and festivals in Spain, Ecuador, Colombia, Peru, Crete, Brazil, China, the Czech Republic and Germany.
http://www.joselezcano.com/

Cellist Rebecca Hartka has concertized for over a decade in venues throughout the United States as well as making international appearances in Italy, Vietnam, and Thailand. Hartka's playing was described by the Hanoi Times as ""... magical and eloquent."" Committed to building bridges through performance Hartka has performed in nontraditional venues such as Club Passim in Cambridge, Massachusetts, the Hampshire County Jail, numerous coffee houses and private homes, and such prestigious venues as the American Embassy in Hanoi. According to the Boston Musical Intelligencer her 2014 release Light & Shadow: Sonatas of Rachmaninov and Poulenc with pianist Alys Terrien-Queen ""take this rich Russian music to new heights"", stating that their performance ""ranks comfortably alongside several impressive readings by other major cellists."" Hartka earned her Doctorate of Musical Arts and Masters in Music from Boston University College of Fine Arts, and her Bachelor of Arts in Music from Oberlin College and Conservatory. She has studied with Andor Toth, Michael Reynolds, Rhonda Rider, and Leslie Parnas.
http://rebeccahartka.com/
More about the Cuba Project

As a duo travelling to Cuba we have the opportunity to be cultural ambassadors, to build bridges through music across language and country, to nurture understanding, compassion and respect for our shared human experience. Our goal is to give voice to an underrepresented community in the Classical music field, and bring something back to share with our community. Our intention is to record a CD of music for cello and guitar by Cuban, Brazilian, Argentinian and American composers. Included on the CD would be Lezcano’s own duo.
Costs

One of the largest expenses associated with this project is the cost of purchasing the cello to be donated. IN addition, traveling with a cello and bow requires an extra airplane seat, as cellos cannot be checked as baggage. The other large expense is the cost of studio time. We have chosen to work with the Fraser studio at WGBH in Boston, and though they have a reasonable rate, it takes about 15 hours of recording time to create a one hour CD. Other costs include editing, printing and production of the CD.
A basic break down of costs:
$3, 000 Cello and Bow
$1,000 plane tickets
$1,300 tour costs
$3,500 CD recording
Total: $8,800
Risks

We run the risk of falling short of the fundraising goal. This is an ambitious endeavor, and we have little of our own money to devote to this project. If we are unable to reach our goal, we will simply take our time with CD project, recording as we have the money to fund it. Since we have already committed to our trip to Cuba, the tour and travel expenses will take first priority.
Please note, as of January 2015, it IS legal to donate goods beyond food and medicine to Cuba from the USA. I quote a document from the Covington Law Firm:
The BIS rule also enacts changes that
seek to facilitate donations to Cuba and promote civil society and human
rights. License Exception SCP permits
the donation of items to Cuba for use in scientific, archaeological, cultural,
ecological, educational, historic preservation, or sporting activities, as
well as the temporary export of such items for up to two years by persons departing
the United States. The license exception also authorizes the export of certain
items to human rights organizations, individuals, or non-governmental
organizations that promote independent activity intended to strengthen civil
society, and the export of certain items to media personnel in Cuba engaged in
the dissemination of news to the general public. In addition, BIS expanded
License Exception Gift Parcels and Humanitarian Donations (“GFT”) to allow
consolidated shipments to Cuba of multiple parcels of qualified gifts or
donations without a license.
Heres a link to the full PDF document:
https://www.cov.com/~/media/files/corporate/publications/2015/01/us_treasury_and_commerce_departments_issue_amended_regulations_to_ease_us_sanctions_against_cuba.pdf
And a link to the US treasury department website outlining these changes

To strengthen civil society, SCP will authorize export and reexport of donated items and temporary export and reexport by travelers to Cuba of items for use in scientific, archaeological, cultural, ecological, educational, historic preservation, or sporting activities.  SCP will also authorize exports and reexports to human rights organizations, individuals, or non-governmental organizations that promote independent activity intended to strengthen civil society.
https://www.treasury.gov/press-center/press-rel...
In conclusion

Cultural exchange is possible through the language of music. When musicians from different cultures connect across barriers, it creates a more peaceful and humane world. Education for fellow musicians in Cuba means that opportunity for talented music students can be more fully developed and share with their community. Bringing different voices into the Classical field brings richness and vibrance. Donating a cello is a pioneering effort only legally available to US citizens as of 18 months ago.
If you are unable to donate
You can support our project by letting other people know about our fundraising efforts by sharing on social media.",0.0,0,"2 Campaigns

While studying photography in my sophomore year in college I was given the task to discover an 'alternative process'. Cyanotype, also knows as blue prints or sun prints can be a rewarding yet somewhat frustrating form of photographic printing. It involves coating paper in a two part UV light sensitive emulsion and once dry placing the coated paper attached to a negative under a UV light source to expose. I have used the sun for years but this can be very frustrating. Exposure times can range from 5 minutes to 30 minutes using the sun method depending on the time of day, season, and weather, therefore a good amount of waste can occur with under and overexposed pieces. With this project I am hoping to raise enough money to purchase a pricey UV exposure unit to use in my home. This will take a good bit of the guess work out of the printing process and allow me to better focus on creating new art rather than spending time chasing the sun.

","If you love great music, join the best tribute recording in a decade: Mosaic - The Jayhawks tribute.
Many music lovers already know the awesome Americana music of The Jayhawks band from Minneapolis, MN.
In 2016, The Jayhawks are reaching the 30th anniversary of their first album. They never sought to chase music trends and just stuck to great songwriting and music.

There is an unbelievable amount of love in the music industry for The Jayhawks and with some organization, that good will is being turned into a big ""Thank You"" from other artists who stand well on their own and love The Jayhawks.
Kicking off the public campaign for this tribute project is a New York City recording session with The Silos.
When The Silos first started out, Rolling Stone magazine named them Best New Band of the Year. Many plaudits have come from music critics for their songwriting as well.

The Silos will be teaming up with Mario McNulty, a Grammy-award winning sound engineer. McNulty's other engineering credits include several albums with David Bowie and others with Alejandro Escevedo, Ziggy Marley & Rufus Wainwright. So between the band and the engineer, we are talking TOP SHELF.
The Preparation
This tribute project has been quietly underway lining up audio engineers and musicians for recording sessions. [There are FOUR Grammy-award winning engineers committed to sessions already.]

A few songs have already been recorded, requiring some mixing work and/or editing video footage to accompany those songs. As you will see with the goal levels, Backers have an opportunity to complete the final stage of those sessions beyond the goal for the NYC session.
One of the first songs recorded for the tribute was done with a collaboration of top session musicians in Nashville, comprised of Ken Coomer, the original drummer of Wilco
column2: Mike Daly, a sideman for Hank Williams, Jr and Travis Tritt (pedal steel player on this project)
column3: Supe Granda, a founding member of the Ozark Mountain Daredevils, on bass
column4: Jim Reilley of The New Dylans, on acoustic
column5: and Michael Webb of country-rock legacy band Poco, on keyboards and accordian.

column1: [Ken Coomer has been producing some great bands like Sons of Bill. Michael Webb did session recording on Sturgill Simpson's critically acclaimed newest album ].
The Budget and Campaign Goals

For the New York City session $2,200 will cover the studio, engineer, stipend for the musicians and some small travel costs. For those who already know recording costs, this is quite modest, especially for the caliber of talent involved.
There are some unique perks - photos from the recording session, a test pressing of the vinyl record, a listing in the album credits, all the way up to sitting in on the session.

Going beyond the recording session goal, at 118 percent, Backers will make possible the editing of the video footage to go with the song.  125 percent covers some music licensing fees. 140 percent of the goal will allow video editing to be done for a December 2014 session with The Last Hombres in New York, and Backers will be the first to experience the finished product!
[In March 2015 The Last Hombres started working their way up the US Roots 66 chart]

If enough people hear about this project and get engaged and become Backers, 158 percent will cover the costs for the video of the session with Coomer, Webb and the boys in Nashville and Backers will get to experience it right here! The more Backers, more gets done on this phase of the campaign!
Risks & Challenges
A tribute project involves more moving parts than a band or solo artist recording. About 38,000 travel miles have been accumulated to get to this point!

Backers get the benefit of the groundwork being done in advance. Instead of starting from scratch, an investment was made with the first Nashville session as a demonstration project to recruit the other bands and solo artists for the tribute.

Funding for recording sessions will be done in segments. There are a lot of projects out there where a campaign is limited to a copy of the recording. With segments, there will be more opportunities to engage a lot of music fans.

Some segment  examples, two solo artists recordings for this project in Nashville, a session in Los Angeles with a band and two special guests and recording sessions in Memphis & North Carolina. The artists know the game plan. It's like laying bricks.

The preparation work for the project has allowed some issues to be identified in advance. In June 2014, for example, all record plants in the United States were at full capacity. This means it is taking a few months longer to get a finished vinyl product and that has been taken into account.
Other Ways You Can Help
Getting the word out to others through social media and telling other music lovers is very valuable. Thank you in advance for getting the word out and making some noise about the campaign.
Using the Indiegogo share tools in your posts will connect other music fans directly to the campaign.
Thank You and Let's Do This!
(non-US mailed items incur additional shipping charges.)
(the ""Picture This"" perk is no longer available)",0.0,0,"1 Campaign
|","Nashville, United States",https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/mosaic-the-jayhawks-tribute-album/pica

","Hello, Beautiful People!I’m Stacie Collins. Thanks for checking out my project. I’m thrilled to announce that I am once again teaming up with friends and the folks at IndieGoGo to record my 5th studio album “Roll The Dice” with the help of this special PRE-SALE and fundraising campaign running April 14th thru May 24th, 2015.As a grass-root indie artist, over the last several years, I have managed to write, record and release 4 records and a Live DVD with my super talented songwriter/bass playing husband Al Collins. We live in Nashville, TN and have been married for 28 glorious years. Touring heavily over the last 7 years with with our slam-bang rock 'n' roll band I call The AL-Mighty Three, we have been fortunate to play some of the best festivals and clubs around the world which has been the catalyst for our music. With no major label or financial support, it's been word of mouth, internet radio airplay and folks coming to the shows and buying our records that keep our music alive. During the last year, Al and I have written a bunch of new songs so we decided to cut a new record. Our band for the recording includes Dan Baird and Audley Freed on guitars, Brad Pemberton on drums, Al Collins on bass, Michael Webb on keys and Lisa Oliver-Gray on BV’s. We’ve already started recording the tracks and soon I’ll start posting some samples! If you love music or the indie artists that make it and would like to help support this project, you can contribute directly and PRE-ORDER your copy of the new record or any of the Thank You gifts. In exchange for your support, we have all kinds of cool and EXCLUSIVE ""THANK YOU"" gifts called ""perks"" to choose from including once in a lifetime experiences, signed band items or my first hat worn on the cover of my 1st record (out of print). To “sweeten” the deal, you can even choose some of my homemade baked goods. Some of the “perks” are limited and new items will be listed as we go.Every contribution large or small will help will help reach our goal amount of $20,000 and we will be most grateful. This goal will cover the costs of making the record plus allow for a modest budget for promotion. Something I’ve never had in the past! Whether or not you can contribute financially, you can help by spreading the word about this campaign. Share with your friends through Facebook, Twitter and email. Do you know someone who likes projects like this and would like to make a difference? Send it their way!When will the record be released? The official release is August 2015. Everyone who rolls the dice with us will get the advance downloads, hard copies and thank you gifts when it's finished.

What does our music sound like? I've always been a bit hard to nail down when it comes to this subject. I think it's just good ol' fashioned Roots Rock but don’t take my word for it. Have a listen when you visit www.staciecollins.com or YouTube channel  http://youtube.com/staciecollinsmusic. You can also find our previous releases on CD Baby, iTunes, Spotify, Pandora and many more music sites.

Thank You!  Above all, Al and I want to thank all our supporters, friends and fan/families in advance for believing in our music. You mean the world to us and remain the fuel for our fire! We REALLY love the new songs and think you will too! With a little luck, a lot of preparation and hard work, we'll soon be able to share with the world... the record you helped make possible!
Sometimes Ya Gotta... ROLL THE DICE... to find The Lucky Spot!
Cheers, Salute, Prost, 乾杯, Chinchín and Skål Ya'll!

Now preparing to begin its 53rd season, The Taos School of Music provides 19 scholarships to current students or recent graduates of the most respected music conservatories around the country. These young artists come to the Taos Ski Valley for eight weeks of intensive work with a faculty of professional chamber music performers.   During the eight week term the students are assembled into ensembles which perform in concerts at the ski valley and in the town of Taos.

More than 700 alumni of the school have had their professional music careers enhanced by their experience at TSOM.  These artists have performed with orchestras, as soloists and/or as members of ensembles, sharing classical music with audiences across the country.

The school and I have agreed to cooperate on a project to capture this season, from auditions, to rehearsals with the young artists working with professional mentors, to the final performances.  I will then seek to have the project published as a coffee table book.  A significant share of the proceeds from sales of the book and any ancillary sold images will benefit the school.

The funds raised will permit me to acquire newly available professional photographic equipment.  This new technology is silent and permits the capture of rehearsals, tutoring sessions and performances, without disturbing the performers or their audiences.  The funds will also underwrite travel expenses related to the project and for collaborators working on producing the text and the design with me.

I have designed a schedule of perks which will be provided to contributors at different levels.  These perks include limited edition fine art prints of images captured during the project, as well as signed copies of the book which I hope to have published at the end of the project.
column2:
>  

Like all non profit organizations, The Taos School of Music will find any funds generated by the project to be helpful in continuing its mission.  Importantly, any attendant publicity about the school shared with the general public will also help the school and support its growth.

I have pursued photography since spending a year in the far east in the early 1960's.  Until I retired from a legal career six years ago (practicing for 25 years and serving as a federal administrative judge for 15), my photographic work was an avocational passion.  Since retiring, I have shown my work in galleries in Taos and Dallas, on line, and at art shows in a number of states.  While I no longer travel the art festival circuit, I continue to pursue the art of photography.   Some of my past work can be seen at
column8:
/a"" rel=""noopener nofollow"" target=""_blank"">www.davidrosenbergphotography.com.

In addition, I will be working with a good friend of mine for more than fifty years, Richard Freed, in the writing of the text for the book.  Richard, a two time Fulbright Scholar, is Professor Emeritus at Eastern Kentucky University where he taught English language and literature for thirty years.

","Now preparing to begin its 53rd season, The Taos School of Music provides 19 scholarships to current students or recent graduates of the most respected music conservatories around the country. These young artists come to the Taos Ski Valley for eight weeks of intensive work with a faculty of professional chamber music performers.   During the eight week term the students are assembled into ensembles which perform in concerts at the ski valley and in the town of Taos.More than 700 alumni of the school have had their professional music careers enhanced by their experience at TSOM.  These artists have performed with orchestras, as soloists and/or as members of ensembles, sharing classical music with audiences across the country.The school and I have agreed to cooperate on a project to capture this season, from auditions, to rehearsals with the young artists working with professional mentors, to the final performances.  I will then seek to have the project published as a coffee table book.  A significant share of the proceeds from sales of the book and any ancillary sold images will benefit the school.The funds raised will permit me to acquire newly available professional photographic equipment.  This new technology is silent and permits the capture of rehearsals, tutoring sessions and performances, without disturbing the performers or their audiences.  The funds will also underwrite travel expenses related to the project and for collaborators working on producing the text and the design with me.I have designed a schedule of perks which will be provided to contributors at different levels.  These perks include limited edition fine art prints of images captured during the project, as well as signed copies of the book which I hope to have published at the end of the project.  Like all non profit organizations, The Taos School of Music will find any funds generated by the project to be helpful in continuing its mission.  Importantly, any attendant publicity about the school shared with the general public will also help the school and support its growth.  I am hopeful and determined that there will be meaningful proceeds to be shared with the school
column10: however, contributors should realize that risks are inherent in any artistic endeavor.I have pursued photography since spending a year in the far east in the early 1960's.  Until I retired from a legal career six years ago (practicing for 25 years and serving as a federal administrative judge for 15), my photographic work was an avocational passion.  Since retiring, I have shown my work in galleries in Taos and Dallas, on line, and at art shows in a number of states.  While I no longer travel the art festival circuit, I continue to pursue the art of photography.   Some of my past work can be seen at  www.davidrosenbergphotography.com.In addition, I will be working with a good friend of mine for more than fifty years, Richard Freed, in the writing of the text for the book.  Richard, a two time Fulbright Scholar, is Professor Emeritus at Eastern Kentucky University where he taught English language and literature for thirty years.Please consider making a contribution to the project.  Also, and importantly, please share this Indiegogo crowdfunding campaign with colleagues, friends and family members.",0.0,0,"1 Campaign

If you could do anything, and you would not fail, what would it be...

I am no one with a name. I have hopes, goals and aspirations. I am you, you are me.
We hope and we dream, but do we do? Do we take action to make our dreams reality, or do we open our eyes and let them fade away?
<blockquote>
<span style=""font-style: italic
column6: >When you sing with a group of people, you learn how to subsume yourself into a group consciousness because a capella singing is all about the immersion of the self into the community. That's one of the great feelings - to stop being me for a little while and to become us. That way lies empathy, the great social virtue. -

column1: <blockquote>Singing is a way of escaping. It's another world. I'm no longer on earth.  -<span style=""color: rgb(106, 106, 106)

This campaign is to fund an album that has been waiting in the ground dormant to emerge as a flower. It is my passion, and the first thing I have really decided to focus every part of my being on making a reality.
Any contribution makes it possible for me to be able to pay musicians, producers, studio time, create merchandise, build a home studio, and ultimately, produce an album.
Your donation will help me fund:
<ul>
• $450 will go toward print CDs and packaging
• Copyright fees and registration with performance-rights nonprofits
• Purchase of a mic and editing programs
• Graphic design, videography, and marketing collateral
• Recording studio fees

I believe that it is from #NationalGeographic. A group of children was told if they raced who ever won could have a basket of fruit. So they all joined hands and took to the finish line all winning together, so that the fruit was shared with everyone. 

Risks &

No matter how hard we plan, things never turn out as expected. I might have technical difficulties. Dates might get pushed back. But, this will become a finished product! I won't give up, and I won't let you down.
Wanna Help?
Share this. The more eyes that see it, the better the odds.

","If you could do anything, and you would not fail, what would it be... I am no one with a name. I have hopes, goals and aspirations. I am you, you are me.

column1: We hope and we dream, but do we do? Do we take action to make our dreams reality, or do we open our eyes and let them fade away?

When you sing with a group of people, you learn how to subsume yourself into a group consciousness because a capella singing is all about the immersion of the self into the community. That's one of the great feelings - to stop being me for a little while and to become us. That way lies empathy, the great social virtue. -Brian Eno
Singing is a way of escaping. It's another world. I'm no longer on earth.  -Edith Piaf

This campaign is to fund an album that has been waiting in the ground dormant to emerge as a flower. It is my passion, and the first thing I have really decided to focus every part of my being on making a reality.
Any contribution makes it possible for me to be able to pay musicians, producers, studio time, create merchandise, build a home studio, and ultimately, produce an album.
Your donation will help me fund:
$450 will go toward print CDs and packaging
Copyright fees and registration with performance-rights nonprofits
Purchase of a mic and editing programs
Graphic design, videography, and marketing collateral
Recording studio fees
If the goal is reached, I will distribute up to 10% of the proceeds to other indiegogos. If the goal is exceeded, I will donate 15% back to indiegogo.
I will also print records if I exceed my goal.
If the goal isn't reached, I will put all of the money toward making sure that perks are fulfilled.
The Impact
These contributions will make it possible for me to start becoming a self-sufficient artist given the proper nutrition. This project is valuable if it's deemed it that way. It is up to you.

I have successfully made the video and the fight song, so hopefully you can hear and see the potential. No matter what, I will not stop doing this. Your help will just make me reach the finish line faster. It is almost like a story I heard a long time ago. I believe that it is from #NationalGeographic. A group of children was told if they raced who ever won could have a basket of fruit. So they all joined hands and took to the finish line all winning together, so that the fruit was shared with everyone.     Risks & Challenges

No matter how hard we plan, things never turn out as expected. I might have technical difficulties. Dates might get pushed back. But, this will become a finished product! I won't give up, and I won't let you down.
Wanna Help?
Share this. The more eyes that see it, the better the odds. Even if all you have is a smile. Thank you! You are beautiful.",0.0,0,"1 Campaign

Short Summary

''PagalmsFest'' is a music festival which for the forth year is being held in Latvia, Sigulda district , on the 3rd and 4th of July. The festival is postitioning itself as an uncomercial music and arts festival. Not only will the festival offer many artist and band performances, but it will also give the guests a chance to participate in various activities. „PagalmsFest” is described by: music, art, sports, cinematography and other types of creative activities. The purpose of „Pagalmsfest” is to promote different art and creativity based sub-culture movements, their development and popularisation in Latvia and the Baltics in general.
Where is Latvia?
The financial support we need for PagalmsFest: 7500 EUR
The money will be invested  in Stage, Lights, Audio, Sound Engineering 3000 EUR
column2: Infrastructure, Transportation, Electricity, Water, Catering 1500 EUR
column3: Security, Staff, Bands, Music licenses, Advertisement etc. 3000 EUR

The Impact

PagalmsFest is growing in size, popularity and ambition every year. Many local and foreign artists are showing their interest in participating in this event. Previous years we have had artists from Finland, Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, France and Spain. This project is about giving a chance for the artists to popularize their work and expose themselfs to new audiences. And for all the festivals visitors we hope to create a place where they can relax, make new friends and explore their creativity in many different and exciting ways.

column2:
Challenges

Producing a music festival takes a lot of time, patience and resources, but we have a dedicated team of family and friends, all of whom are ready to work hard to create something we hope everyone can enjoy! And with your help ''PagalmsFest 2015'' can be bigger and better than ever before!

column8: >My name is Jimmy Galloway.  I am working on a new album titled Tarheel Traveler. My style is a mixture of folk based americana, roots rock, fusion, psychedelia...

column5: >In my years working and playing in Nashville, I was always intrigued by the idea of marrying Appalachian music with Eastern influences.  Just recently I was presented with the opportunity to make that dream a reality.  My college buddy, Damon Whittemore, who has worked on projects that have won multiple Grammys, saw a post of me playing the sitar and said ""Let's do this.""

column1: This album is going to be Chet Atkins meets Buddy Miller meets Neil Young meets Shakti meets Michael Hedges meets Soundgarden meets Richard Thompson....
Along with several deeply talented friends I am going to lay down the beginning tracks here in Atlanta at the sacred space - Southern Tracks Studios.  Once we finish here,
column5: >we will send it around the world to blossom.  One song will head first to Pakistan, then to India to add traditional Eastern instruments - sitar, tabla, harmonium.  Several will move to South America to add some percussion.  Then it will return to the states, this time to New York so Damon can work his magic massaging it all together into a thing of musical beauty.

column3: >I am so excited to get started on this project.  I truly hope that you find it as interesting as I do and are willing to make a contribution to make it a reality.

column1: ","My name is Jimmy Galloway.  I am working on a new album titled Tarheel Traveler. My style is a mixture of folk based americana, roots rock, fusion, psychedelia...

In my years working and playing in Nashville, I was always intrigued by the idea of marrying Appalachian music with Eastern influences.  Just recently I was presented with the opportunity to make that dream a reality.  My college buddy, Damon Whittemore, who has worked on projects that have won multiple Grammys, saw a post of me playing the sitar and said ""Let's do this.""
This album is going to be Chet Atkins meets Buddy Miller meets Neil Young meets Shakti meets Michael Hedges meets Soundgarden meets Richard Thompson....

Along with several deeply talented friends I am going to lay down the beginning tracks here in Atlanta at the sacred space - Southern Tracks Studios.  Once we finish here, we will send it around the world to blossom.  One song will head first to Pakistan, then to India to add traditional Eastern instruments - sitar, tabla, harmonium.  Several will move to South America to add some percussion.  Then it will return to the states, this time to New York so Damon can work his magic massaging it all together into a thing of musical beauty.
I am so excited to get started on this project.  I truly hope that you find it as interesting as I do and are willing to make a contribution to make it a reality.
Here is our budget.
Item
Budget
Production (Recording, Musicians, Studio Time)
Post-Production (Mixing & Mastering)
Fulfillment and Management (CDs, Perks and Fees)
Total
Now let's talk about what's in it for you!! Cool perks include:  big piles of great, nutritious dog food care of Jimmy's non music endeavor - Intown Healthy Hound Pet Store
column4: and my personal favorite - a camping/fishing trip with Jimmy!

column1: If every music friend we have were to contribute just $5 each, we would more than hit our goal.  So do what you can and know we will be there for you in the future.

Whether you are able to make a donation or not, please help us spread the word. Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, Bullhorns from your rooftop, Paper Airplanes, whatever works.  Tell all your friends to check out this project.  Join us on our journey to create a musical treasure.",0.0,0,"1 Campaign

This campaign is raising funds through the East Allegheny Community Council, a registered 501(c)(3) organization. Your contributions will be tax deductible.
All funds raised for this campaign will be designated solely to the bands that are playing in the Deutschtown Music Festival.
<h2 style=""text-align: center
<h2 style=""text-align: center
Get ready for another exciting year,
our third, with over 100 musical acts of varying styles
outdoor stages and indoor venues during the day then spilling out across 15
music venues throughout the night - all within walking distance. ALL FOR FREE!
column2:
>

All contributions from this campaign will go directly to the performers.

column1: The Deutschtown Music Festival is
unique in that it is a free, non-profit event run by volunteers with the goal
of promoting the Northside as well as local musicians and artists.
Months of planning go into this event to provide a full day of music and art,
for free, all within the confines of the East Ohio Street business
district.
<span style=""letter-spacing: 0px
<div>
<div>
<div>
But now is the time to give back to
those that make this happen – the musicians.
We need your support to pay back all
of the great musicians and bands that make this happen. We need to hit our
$10,000 goal – not only because it provides some monetary value back to the
performers but also because it sends the message that we value the time and
effort of each and every performer that will grace a stage during this year’s
festival.
How will our funding be distributed?
Evenly. We are going to attempt to pay each band or performer on a per capita
basis, meaning that each and every person will get the same amount. This
festival was borne out of the idea of community and the greater good and we
hope to spread compensation around fairly.
What can you expect this summer?
Family-friendly daytime activities
include live music on three outdoor stages, three indoor venues, multiple food
vendors stationed around the festival, artist exhibitions, mobile art carts, a
pop-up pinball arcade at Artists Image Resource and other activities.
Nighttime activities include music
and events spread throughout the neighborhood with over 80 different local acts
performing in 9 unique venues, all within walking distance.
The Deutschtown Music Festival has,
in only two years, gained a reputation as one of the premiere summer music
festivals in Pittsburgh.

","This campaign is raising funds through the East Allegheny Community Council, a registered 501(c)(3) organization. Your contributions will be tax deductible. All funds raised for this campaign will be designated solely to the bands that are playing in the Deutschtown Music Festival.
The 2015 Deutschtown Music Festival
Saturday July 11, 2015
Get ready for another exciting year,
our third, with over 100 musical acts of varying styles
outdoor stages and indoor venues during the day then spilling out across 15
music venues throughout the night - all within walking distance. ALL FOR FREE!All contributions from this campaign will go directly to the performers.
The Deutschtown Music Festival is
unique in that it is a free, non-profit event run by volunteers with the goal
of promoting the Northside as well as local musicians and artists.
Months of planning go into this event to provide a full day of music and art,
for free, all within the confines of the East Ohio Street business
district.
But now is the time to give back to
those that make this happen – the musicians.
We need your support to pay back all
of the great musicians and bands that make this happen. We need to hit our
$10,000 goal – not only because it provides some monetary value back to the
performers but also because it sends the message that we value the time and
effort of each and every performer that will grace a stage during this year’s
festival.
How will our funding be distributed?
Evenly. We are going to attempt to pay each band or performer on a per capita
basis, meaning that each and every person will get the same amount. This
festival was borne out of the idea of community and the greater good and we
hope to spread compensation around fairly.
What can you expect this summer?
Family-friendly daytime activities
include live music on three outdoor stages, three indoor venues, multiple food
vendors stationed around the festival, artist exhibitions, mobile art carts, a
pop-up pinball arcade at Artists Image Resource and other activities.
Nighttime activities include music
and events spread throughout the neighborhood with over 80 different local acts
performing in 9 unique venues, all within walking distance.
The Deutschtown Music Festival has,
in only two years, gained a reputation as one of the premiere summer music
festivals in Pittsburgh.

column34: >Studio Grand has a mysterious tendency to pop in and out of existence so you find it just when you're meant to. It's just one of those places... A place where people have momentous epiphanies in voice class
column35: brilliant artists who have a conflicted relationship with gallery-culture find a home
column36: children come to trust and honor their creativity
column37: spirits are lifted while learning Afro-Puerto Rican Bomba Traditional Dance rhythms and moving to soca beats
column38: hearts are opened with poetry and storytelling nights, whole audiences are stunned, moved, awed, shaken, and soothed by formidable musicians, all in an intimate space with a living room feel and gorgeous gallery looks.

column4: >Holly Schneider, Studio Grand's founder, envisioned a welcoming space where artists and community members could experiment, teach, create, study, collaborate, and perform. A local resident and parent herself, Holly was invested in seeing more family-friendly entertainment options in the neighborhood.

>She wanted top-quality arts and music to be available to the entire community. Admission to Studio Grand shows is charged on a sliding scale and classes are affordable. (Help us get those scholarships out and they'll be even more so!) Holly adamantly believed in the value of artists and their work, prioritizing payment to artists while keeping Studio costs to a minimum, and often insistently teaching artists (and, by extension, all of us) not to underestimate their—our—worth. She took those personal challenges common to the passionate and creative soul, and she found a way to share her hard-earned wisdom, strength, and love.
>Holly grew up in New York and Florida surrounded by musicians
column5: her father managed the Rolling Stones in the 70’s. Holly moved to Oakland in 1999. She taught herself how to read music and became an inspired musician. Holly was involved in the local experimental music scene and worked in genres ranging from punk to classical. She was also a member of the Bay Area’s all-women’s Bomba ensemble Las Bomberas de la Bahia. She became an admired dancer. She became a beloved music teacher. She raised a son who has grown up to be a phenomenal Oakland musician and composer.

column4: >With a constant flow of creativity and a desire to imagine a sweeter world, Holly had a nagging call to create something meaningful here in Oakland, the city where she raised her son and found so many people she so dearly loved.

>In September 2013, Holly opened Studio Grand with the support of family, friends, and generous seed funding. Circumstances aligned and Holly's eagerness to make a beautiful, bold difference blossomed into Studio Grand.

>Holly rallied great musicians from around the Bay Area and beyond to come share music of all genres. The Studio hosted Diana Gameros, Oakland Future Trio, Antique Naked Soul, Maria Jose Montijo, Chuck Johnson, Alex Vittum, Aram Shelton, Maria Del Pilar, Motoko Honda, Fantastico Negrito, Marina LaValle, Theresa Wong, Irene Diaz, to name a few. Holly felt that instead of dispersing into increasingly specialized venues, musicians could see themselves all rooted in the same traditions, and come together to challenge and support each other in a shared space. For the first visual exhibit, Artist Matthew Scheatzle graciously hung his meticulous sculptural work at the Studio. Since then, Susan Matthews, Random Parts Gallery Artists, and Sung Kim have hung beautiful shows in the space and will be hosting a piece by Chip Thomas in December 2014. Play and music classes for the little ones were swiftly in place. Claire Gendler taught sold out sessions of voice classes for adults. Studio Grand was up and running towards a bright future.

>In May of this year, we lost Holly to a very quick battle with cancer. Holly's family and friends, new and old, rushed to be by her side. Though the sudden loss left us with shock and heartache, Holly herself left us with love and teachings that are still unfolding and a heartening vision for Studio Grand.

>Wherever Holly is now, she’s also left us a fire under our butts to keep the Studio flourishing for Oakland and all those touched by her work and her light. Holly’s husband decided to keep Studio Grand going and has enlisted a talented and capable collection of Holly’s friends to continue Holly's work. The Studio is also blessed with a dedicated group of volunteers and curators.

>We hope you’ll join us in keeping this dream alive and growing. Together we can make 2015 an amazing year for our growing Studio Grand community with exceptional music, art, and classes. We will strive to continue generating the warmth, support, and inspiration the Studio is known for.
>- keep our Artist-in-Residence program going strong
>- soundproof our walls so we can have performances throughout the day
>- cover the cost of bringing in visual art exhibitions
>- launch our internship and arts-venue learning program
>- offer stipends to artists and long-time volunteers
>- expand our class offerings and allow us to offer scholarships
>- revamp our sound and lighting setup for performances
>- cover our rent in a commercial zone
>- provide staff salaries to take care of day-to-day operations

>Thank you for reading through our campaign. Whether or not you're able to give a monetary gift, you can share our campaign with your friends on Facebook or via email (see Indiegogo share options). We would also love for you to volunteer! Feel free to stop by, or visit our website for more information. We deeply appreciate your participation, whatever form you choose.
>With many thanks and lots of love,<span style=""font: 16.0px 'Lucida Grande'

","Studio Grand has a mysterious tendency to pop in and out of existence so you find it just when you're meant to. It's just one of those places... A place where people have momentous epiphanies in voice class

column5: hearts are opened with poetry and storytelling nights, whole audiences are stunned, moved, awed, shaken, and soothed by formidable musicians, all in an intimate space with a living room feel and gorgeous gallery looks.

column1: Holly Schneider, Studio Grand's founder, envisioned a welcoming space where artists and community members could experiment, teach, create, study, collaborate, and perform. A local resident and parent herself, Holly was invested in seeing more family-friendly entertainment options in the neighborhood.

She wanted top-quality arts and music to be available to the entire community. Admission to Studio Grand shows is charged on a sliding scale and classes are affordable. (Help us get those scholarships out and they'll be even more so!) Holly adamantly believed in the value of artists and their work, prioritizing payment to artists while keeping Studio costs to a minimum, and often insistently teaching artists (and, by extension, all of us) not to underestimate their—our—worth. She took those personal challenges common to the passionate and creative soul, and she found a way to share her hard-earned wisdom, strength, and love.
Holly grew up in New York and Florida surrounded by musicians
column2: her father managed the Rolling Stones in the 70’s. Holly moved to Oakland in 1999. She taught herself how to read music and became an inspired musician. Holly was involved in the local experimental music scene and worked in genres ranging from punk to classical. She was also a member of the Bay Area’s all-women’s Bomba ensemble Las Bomberas de la Bahia. She became an admired dancer. She became a beloved music teacher. She raised a son who has grown up to be a phenomenal Oakland musician and composer.

column1: With a constant flow of creativity and a desire to imagine a sweeter world, Holly had a nagging call to create something meaningful here in Oakland, the city where she raised her son and found so many people she so dearly loved.

In September 2013, Holly opened Studio Grand with the support of family, friends, and generous seed funding. Circumstances aligned and Holly's eagerness to make a beautiful, bold difference blossomed into Studio Grand.

Holly rallied great musicians from around the Bay Area and beyond to come share music of all genres. The Studio hosted Diana Gameros, Oakland Future Trio, Antique Naked Soul, Maria Jose Montijo, Chuck Johnson, Alex Vittum, Aram Shelton, Maria Del Pilar, Motoko Honda, Fantastico Negrito, Marina LaValle, Theresa Wong, Irene Diaz, to name a few. Holly felt that instead of dispersing into increasingly specialized venues, musicians could see themselves all rooted in the same traditions, and come together to challenge and support each other in a shared space. For the first visual exhibit, Artist Matthew Scheatzle graciously hung his meticulous sculptural work at the Studio. Since then, Susan Matthews, Random Parts Gallery Artists, and Sung Kim have hung beautiful shows in the space and will be hosting a piece by Chip Thomas in December 2014. Play and music classes for the little ones were swiftly in place. Claire Gendler taught sold out sessions of voice classes for adults. Studio Grand was up and running towards a bright future.

In May of this year, we lost Holly to a very quick battle with cancer. Holly's family and friends, new and old, rushed to be by her side. Though the sudden loss left us with shock and heartache, Holly herself left us with love and teachings that are still unfolding and a heartening vision for Studio Grand.

Wherever Holly is now, she’s also left us a fire under our butts to keep the Studio flourishing for Oakland and all those touched by her work and her light. Holly’s husband decided to keep Studio Grand going and has enlisted a talented and capable collection of Holly’s friends to continue Holly's work. The Studio is also blessed with a dedicated group of volunteers and curators.

We hope you’ll join us in keeping this dream alive and growing. Together we can make 2015 an amazing year for our growing Studio Grand community with exceptional music, art, and classes. We will strive to continue generating the warmth, support, and inspiration the Studio is known for.
We need your support to:
- keep our Artist-in-Residence program going strong
- soundproof our walls so we can have performances throughout the day
- cover the cost of bringing in visual art exhibitions
- launch our internship and arts-venue learning program
- offer stipends to artists and long-time volunteers
- expand our class offerings and allow us to offer scholarships
- revamp our sound and lighting setup for performances
- cover our rent in a commercial zone
- cover our utilities and internet
- provide staff salaries to take care of day-to-day operations

Thank you for reading through our campaign. Whether or not you're able to give a monetary gift, you can share our campaign with your friends on Facebook or via email (see Indiegogo share options). We would also love for you to volunteer! Feel free to stop by, or visit our website for more information. We deeply appreciate your participation, whatever form you choose.
With many thanks and lots of love,
Studio Grand",0.0,0,"2 Campaigns
|","Oakland, United States",https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/continuing-holly-s-dream-studio-grand-oakland/pica

Hello Supporters
Welcome to my indiegogo page! I'm Alexander Stewart singer, songwriter and musician, thanks for popping by!

Following the release of my first album ‘All or nothing at all’ I’ve been working together, writing, arranging and performing songs, with some amazing musicians. My new album will be a collection of both original songs, and some new takes on tunes that I have known, loved and want to share with you, on what will be my most ambitious project to date.

The self-funded album will feature a varying line up from full big band arrangements, orchestrated scores, and backing vocals. The album mixes a blend of jazz. pop, motown and original songs I am excited for you to hear!  All aspects of the process invariably take time and money to create and I am finally in a position to begin recording, and with your support, the album can be finished!

With the preproduction of the album complete, studio time and musicians booked here in the UK, the final stage of the album will be to record strings with an orchestra. Financial constraints make this essential part of the album almost impossible to fund here in the UK. As a result I have found some incredible musicians in Prague, with whom this part of the project can become viable.
It’s with your involvement I can complete this album and share it with you on it's release this summer.
Become a supporter!
<div>We need at least £5000 (around 25% of the total costs) to complete the album. Your money will go towards:<ul>
• Recording with the orchestra in Prague along with studio hire
• Mixing
• Mastering of the record
• Manufacturing the finished album
• PR for the finished product which will help spread the word

Any level of your amazing support for this record will mean the absolute world and be rewarded with varying perks! From signed copies of the new album, to personally written postcards from Prague. How about a private concert in your living room? Or VIP tickets to one of my shows? There is something for every level of your support.
Other Ways You Can Help

If you don't feel you are in a position to contribute financially, please don't think your support in other ways isnt equally as valuable!! Spread the word about this campaign and the album to your friends, family, colleagues, dogs, cats and ANYONE who will listen. Link to and share the page on facebook, twitter, your blogs and website, in newspapers, over the radio waves and via carrier pigeon or by any other means to help spread the word about the record.
Thank you for your time reading all this and I am immensely excited to have you all be a part of making this second record something incredibly special!
Love
Alexander xxxx

column3:
